Plan A Report 2020, pg. 11 "RENEWABLE ELECTRICITY** This year, 86% of the electricity purchased for M&S operated stores, offices and warehouses worldwide came from on-site generation or green tariff renewable sources. This is down from 100% last year due to the exclusion of international stores, Food warehouses and some Clothing & Home warehouses where renewable electricity tariffs are not in place." pg. 4 "This report is the final update on performance against commitments last updated in 2017." Plan A Report 2018, pg. 29 "RENEWABLE ELECTRICITY** Aim Between 2017 and 2035, 100% of electricity purchased for M&S operated stores, offices and warehouses worldwide will be classified as renewable. Progress This year, all the electricity purchased for M&S operated stores, offices and warehouses worldwide came from on-site generation, green tariff renewable sources, or was supported by renewable electricity certificates. World Benchmarking Alliance+CHRB D.1.10 Women's rights+World Benchmarking Alliance Research Group
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.1.A Commitment to Respect Human Rights
Comments: The company has a publicly available policy statement committing it to respect human rights, which is approved by the highest governance body.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.1.A Commitment to Respect Human Rights+World Benchmarking Alliance Research Group
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.10.A Living Wage Targets
Comments: The company states that all colleagues are paid at or above the real living wage in London. However, no evidence found that the company discloses a time-bound target for paying all workers a living wage or that it has achieved paying all workers a living wage.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.10.B Living Wage Determination
Comments: The company states that it commissioned research into living wages through a combination of benchmarking exercises, desk-based research, and field research in factories and communities. However, the disclosed information is insufficient to meet the indicator element. Also, no evidence found that the company describes how it determines a living wage for the regions where it operates.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.10.C Living Wage Business Relationship Support
Comments: The company discloses that it has begun reviewing its banana supply chain to understand wage levels along with the support of IDH, the Sustainable Trade Initiative. Also, the company states that it will next verify this information and then use the information to understand the gap that it has per origin to reach the living wage. Additionally, the company discloses a commitment for workers in its banana supply chains to receive a living wage by 2027 alongside its retailer partners coordinated by IDH and supported by partners across the industry.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI 10 Living wage fundamentals
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI 10 Living wage fundamentals+World Benchmarking Alliance Research Group
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.11.A Fair Working Hours Commitment
Comments: The company states that it ensures that the working hours of all its employees comply with national laws or benchmark industry standards or relevant international standards. However, the company has its operations in countries like India and United States, where there is no universal national limit on working hours, thus local regulation would not be sufficient to comply with the indicator requirement. Also, no evidence found that the company publicly states that workers shall not be required to work more than 48 hours in a regular work week or 60 hours including overtime.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.11.B Commitment to Fair Overtime
Comments: The company states that any overtime above contractual requirements is voluntary. However, no evidence found that the company publicly states that all overtime work must be paid at a premium rate.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.11.C Fair Working Hours Commitment in Business Relationship Employees
Comments: The company has a public expectation that its business relationships shall not require workers to work more than 48 hours in a regular work week or 60 hours including overtime.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI 11 Working hours fundamentals
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI 11 Working hours fundamentals+World Benchmarking Alliance Research Group
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.12.A Collective Bargaining
Comments: No evidence found that the company discloses the proportion of its total direct operations workforce covered by collective bargaining agreements.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.12.A Collective Bargaining+World Benchmarking Alliance Research Group
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.12.B Collective Bargaining in Business Relationships
Comments: The company requires its suppliers partners to respect their workers' right to freedom of association, including to form or join associations of their own choice and bargain collectively on all work-related issues. However, no evidence found that the company describes how it works to support the practices of its business relationships in relation to freedom of association and collective bargaining.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.12.B Collective Bargaining in Business Relationships+World Benchmarking Alliance Research Group
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI 12 Collective bargaining fundamentals
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.13.A Workforce Age Diversity Disclosure
Comments: No evidence found that the company discloses the proportion of its total direct operations workforce for each employee category by age group.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.13.B Workforce Gender Diversity Disclosure
Comments: The company discloses the gender of its board of directors and executive committee. [Webpage - Our Leadership] Also, it discloses the proportion of female in its total workforce and senior managers. [Sustainability Report 2023, 67]

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.13.C Workforce Race Diversity Disclosure
Comments: The company discloses its board and executive committee ethnicity. [Annual Report & Financial Statements 2023, 88] However, no evidence found that the company discloses the proportion of its total direct operations workforce for each employee category by race or ethnicity.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.13.D Workforce Other Diversity Disclosure
Comments: No evidence found that the company discloses the proportion of its total direct operations workforce for each employee category by one or more additional indicators of diversity.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI 13 Workforce diversity disclosure fundamentals
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI 13 Workforce diversity disclosure fundamentals+World Benchmarking Alliance Research Group
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.14.A Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment Commitment
Comments: The company has been signatory of WEPs since 20 June 2019. [Webpage - WEPs Signatories]

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.14.B Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment Targets
Comments: The company discloses its time bound target to increase the representation of women in senior managers to 50% by 2025.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.14.C At least 30% Women on Highest Governance Body
Comments: On its website, the company reports that out of 12 board members, 6 are female. The percentage of women on board is 50%. [Webpage - Our Leadership]

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.14.D Gender Pay Ratio Disclosure
Comments: The company discloses the mean gender pay gap for its operations i.e. 12.5%. [Gender Pay Gap Report 2023, PDF 1] However, no evidence found that the company discloses the ratio of the basic salary and remuneration of women to men in its total direct operations workforce for each employee category, by significant locations of operation.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI 14 Gender equality and women’s empowerment fundamentals
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI 14 Gender equality and women’s empowerment fundamentals+World Benchmarking Alliance Research Group
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.15.A Personal Data Protection Commitment
Comments: The company has a public commitment to protecting personal data.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.15.A Personal Data Protection Commitment+World Benchmarking Alliance Research Group
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.15.B Personal Data Protection Policy
Comments: The company has a global publicly available customer privacy policy in relation to the collection, sharing and access to personal data. [Webpage - Privacy Policy] However, no evidence found that the company has a global publicly available privacy statement in relation to the collection, sharing and access to personal data of all stakeholders i.e. employees and customers at a minimum.

Comments: The company has a publicly available global tax strategy, which is approved by the highest governance body.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.16.B Responsible Tax Strategy Accountability
Comments: A governance body or executive-level position is tasked with accountability for compliance with the company’s global tax strategy.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.16.C Corporate Income Tax Disclosure
Comments: The company discloses its current, deferred and total income taxes for the year 2022. [Annual Report & Financial Statements 2023, 164-165] However, no evidence found that the company discloses the amount of corporate income tax paid for each tax jurisdiction where the company is a resident for tax purposes.

World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.17.A Anti-bribery and Anti-Corruption Policy
Comments: The company has a publicly available policy statement prohibiting bribery and corruption.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI 17 Anti-bribery and anti-corruption fundamentals
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI 17 Anti-bribery and anti-corruption fundamentals+World Benchmarking Alliance Research Group
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.17.B Anti-bribery and Anti-Corruption Process
Comments: The company discloses that it conducts bribery risk assessment annually. However, the disclosed information is insufficient to meet the indicator element. Also, no evidence found that the company describes the process to identify its bribery and corruption risks and impacts in specific locations or activities covering its own operations.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.17.C Anti-bribery and Anti-Corruption In Contractual Agreements
Comments: The company includes anti-bribery and anti-corruption clauses in its contracts with business relationships.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.17.D Anti-bribery and Anti-Corruption Complaint Mechanism
Comments: The company discloses a website and contact numbers to raise bribery and corruption concerns and complaints without fear of reprisals. Also, on visiting the website, it is clear that the channel is open to all and the complainants have an option of reporting anonymously or identify himself/herself. [Webpage - Safecall]

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.18.A Responsible Lobbying and Political Engagement Policy
Comments: The company has a publicly available policy statements setting out its lobbying and political engagement approach.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.18.B Political Contributions Policy
Comments: The company has a publicly available policy stating that it does not make political donations. However, no evidence found that the company has a publicly available policy statement that specifies that it does not make political contributions.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.18.C Lobbying Expenditures Disclosure
Comments: No evidence found that the company discloses its expenditures on lobbying activities.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.18.D Third-Party Political Lobbying and Engagement Policy
Comments: No evidence found that the company requires third-party lobbyists to comply with its lobbying and political engagement policy.

World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.3.A Identifying Human Rights Risk and Impacts
Comments: The company discloses that its due diligence strategy is informed by regular updates to internal policies and standards, external research, and risk assessments, with examples such as research on living wages, contributions to studies on workplace grievance mechanisms, and assessments of key risks in sourcing countries. Also, it discloses that it uses external data sets, for example those from the World Bank, ITUC, World Economic Forum, and the Gender Equality Index, to understand human rights risks by geography. Further, it discloses that it undertakes full due diligence before entering any new franchise partnership venture and as part of this process, it gives due consideration to human rights risks at a country and organisational level, and commission specialist external audits where necessary. Furthermore, it discloses that it uses a range of external tools as part of its country level assessment of corporate risk, including Maplecroft Risk Indices and the Transparency International Corruption Percepti...

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.3.A Identifying Human Rights Risk and Impacts+World Benchmarking Alliance Research Group
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.3.B Identifying Business Partner Human Rights Risk and Impacts
Comments: The company discloses that in its Clothing & Home due diligence, suppliers are audited annually by approved independent third party companies and ethical audit process, including grading, escalation and audit follow-up activity and is managed by its specialist Sourcing Office compliance teams. Also, it discloses that it uses external data sets, for example those from the World Bank, ITUC, World Economic Forum, and the Gender Equality Index, to understand human rights risks by geography. Further, it discloses that its due diligence strategy is informed by regular updates to internal policies and standards, external research, and risk assessments, with examples such as research on living wages, contributions to studies on workplace grievance mechanisms, and assessments of key risks in sourcing countries. Furthermore, it discloses that it uses assessments to monitor its supplier partners’ human rights management systems and therefore introduced specialist audits, such as the Gangmasters and Labour Abuse Autho...

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.3.B Identifying Business Partner Human Rights Risk and Impacts+World Benchmarking Alliance Research Group

World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.4.A Assessing Human Rights Risks and Impacts Processes
Comments: The company discloses that risk identification and prioritisation includes the desk-based research, data from our audit programmes, supplier surveys, supply chain due diligence, supplier engagement and discussions with expert stakeholders through multi-stakeholder initiatives. Additionally, it discloses that it has completed its comprehensive assessment in April 2023, and it has updated its Group salient issues i.e. discrimination and gender, forced labour, freedom of association, health and safety, labour exploitation, wages and income and working hours. [Sustainability Report 2023, 40]

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI 4 Assessing human rights risks and impacts
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI 4 Assessing human rights risks and impacts+World Benchmarking Alliance Research Group
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.4.B Assessing Human Rights Risks and Impacts Results
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.5.A Integrating and Acting on Human Rights Risk and Impact Assessments
Comments: The company indicates that it has setup a grievance mechanism and encourages its employees and individuals within its supply chains and wider communities to report any wrongdoing without fear of retribution. Further, the company discloses that it recognises the importance of educating its colleagues about responsible sourcing and human rights, therefore, it has introduced an online training module, ‘People Behind the Product’. Additionally, the company discloses its action plan for mitigating discrimination, safety related risks, forced labour, labour exploitation wage issues.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.5.B Integrating and Acting on Human Rights Risk and Impact Assessments Specific Conclusions

World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.6.A Engaging with Affected and Potentially Affected Stakeholders
Comments: The company lists the stakeholders that it engages with in general on sustainability, i.e. shareholders, colleagues, customers, communities, suppliers, and partners. [Annual Report & Financial Statements 2023, 10-11] However, no evidence found that the company discloses the categories of stakeholders whose human rights have been or may be affected by its activities.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.6.A Engaging with Affected and Potentially Affected Stakeholders+World Benchmarking Alliance Research Group
World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.6.B Engaging with Affected and Potentially Affected Stakeholders Examples
Comments: The company discloses that it conducted study in partnership with Waitrose to gain a deeper understanding of its shared supply chain in Kenya, hearing the views of smallholder farmers, hired labourers and factory workers in the industry and published the Human Rights Impact Assessment (HRIA) of the Kenyan smallholder tea supply chain. Further, the company discloses that it has worked with the Centre for Rehabilitation of the Paralysed “CRP” in Bangladesh to support the people with disabilities to succeed in their communities through skills development training, job placement and economic empowerment and after completion of training it offers employment in its supplier's factories.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.9.B Health and Safety Quantitative Disclosure
Comments: No evidence found that the company discloses quantitative information on health and safety for its workers.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.9.C Health and Safety Business Relationship Commitment
Comments: The company has a publicly available statement of policy that expects its business relationships to commit to respecting the health and safety of their workers.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+CSI.9.D Health and Safety Business Relationship Monitoring
Comments: The company discloses that it routinely carry out technical audits of suppliers on worker health and safety. Further, the company discloses that all of its suppliers are required to be audited frequently by M&S or by approved independent third-party companies. Additionally, it discloses that it request its all high-risk suppliers to undertake semi-announced SMETA (Sedex Members Ethical Trade Audits) bi-annually and share the result with M&S.

Elske Krikhaar+Detox Leader
Comments: MS is in the Leaders group because of its actions, in particular Greenpeace applauds MS for ensuring the publication of data on the discharge of hazardous chemicals by its individual suppliers on the global online platform IPE; it is on track to ensure that 80% of its dyehouses in China (by turnover) publish their discharge data. Greenpeace continues to encourage MS to deliver on its promises on the ‘Precautionary Principle’, the ‘Right to Know’ and ‘Zero Discharges’ and expects it to demonstrate its Detox credentials through on the ground implementation.

Metric: Greenpeace+Detox Transparency
Comments: MS has ensured the publication of data on the discharge of hazardous chemicals by its suppliers on the global online platform IPE. It has extended the number of dye houses that have now taken part in the public disclosure initiative to 52 – this currently represents 56% of MS global turnover and 76% of MS Chinese turnover, in line with its new objective to report data from 80% of dye houses in China (by turnover) by June 2015.

Dina Seyer+Distribute Leftover Food
Comments: We are able to donate various bakery products, produce, flowers and ambient products. By law we are unable to donate any products that have gone past their ‘use by’ date but this is an area the industry is doing some research into. As a largely chilled business this is especially pertinent to us and is of particular interest. Having said this, the current categories of donated products represent up to 45% of our daily waste units. Whilst we’re doing as much as possible to reduce the amount of waste we create in the first place and redistributing what we can there is inevitably a residual portion of waste. This is sent to anaerobic digestion plants. This ultimately creates electricity some of which MS buys back for its own energy supply and produces digestate which can be used as a fertiliser.

Greenpeace+Elimination of APEOs and Phthalates
Comments: MS is delivering on the elimination of hazardous chemicals such as APEOs and phthalates which it has communicated to its global supply chain. It has reported the results of its investigation into the use of APEOs.

Metric: Greenpeace+Elimination of PFCs
Comments: MS is committed to total PFC elimination in textiles by 1st July 2016. It has delivered on the elimination of C8 PFCs and continues to communicate with its suppliers about its phase out of all PFCs. MS was a pioneer when its original Commitment was adopted, as the first brand to set an elimination date for all PFCs and for including all the key principles in its Commitment. MS has a usage ban on phthalates in its Manufacturing-­‐RSL, however, it needs to clarify its elimination of phthalates in final products cover all products range, not only those intended for children (as outlined in its Product‐RSL).

Walk Free+Employee dialogue (sector specific)
Comments: "C&H – We launched a pilot in 9 factories in India at the start of 2021 to hear directly from workers on their experience of working in the supply chain. So far, this pilot has reached 4,025 workers – 4% of the workforce in our Indian supply chain. We have worked with an ethical trade consultancy to develop the questions which ranged from those designed to provide us with an understanding of satisfaction in role, to those aimed at assessing people’s sense of fairness." p. 9 Malene Hand[https://wikirate.org/Malene_Hand].....2021-12-18 18:54:56 UTC

Metric: Walk Free+Employee dialogue (sector specific)
Comments: pg. 8 “In June 2021, we conducted a visit to a Scottish berry supplier partner to review their recruitment process and interview workers on the UK temporary visa scheme. From the interviews it was clear how complex the challenges surrounding the VISA were for the workers involved, including the cost of the VISA itself and the potential impact of the weather on working hours. In December 2021, we conducted a tailored visit to our UK poultry suppliers to review processes and interview workers on the UK temporary visa scheme. We interviewed workers from Ukraine, Belarus, Bulgaria and Romania to understand their recruitment journey, their accommodation in the UK and their workplace.” Pg. 9 “In response, we have carried out due diligence audits and worker interviews in all of our supplier partner factories in China which have not, to date, identified evidence of any forced Uyghur workers in our factories.” Manali Rana[https://wikirate.org/Manali_Rana].....2023-01-09 09:45:43 UTC

Our Anti-Corruption and Anti-Bribery Policy outlines the expected standards of conduct that employees, contractors, suppliers, business partners, and any other third parties who act for and on behalf of M&S, are obliged to follow. The policy also includes detailed procedures around giving and receiving gifts, hospitality and entertainment; procedures for engaging new suppliers and partners, specifically those who are based in higher-risk jurisdictions, and standard contract clauses; and clear reporting channels, including confidential reporting. For colleagues who work in areas that may pose a higher risk, we provide mandatory Anti-Bribery and Anti-Corruption e-learning. The Company will consider taking disciplinary action against anyone who fails to comply with its anti-bribery policy up to and including dismissal. Metric: Clean Clothes Campaign+Isolating Labour Cost
Comments: We continue to implement our mature open costings model and have detailed costing sheets splitting out manufacturing costs for all product categories for all suppliers, which are used in our price negotiations. This must be done in conjunction with the efficiencies of the factory to ensure fair living wages can be paid. And factories must be able to demonstrate open costings, standard minute values for products and labour costs. One of the main tools within our buying teams and the central sourcing team is production planning. Given that we share many factories with other retailers it is vital to work with our suppliers and plan capacity. Therefore we work on 3 year internal supplier production plans and have individual 1 year production order capacity plans agreed with suppliers for the forward production. In conjunction with our annual wage ladders produced we can verify that our cost prices are sufficient to pay fair living wages. Due to the commercial sensitivity of this information we are not able to ...

Walk Free+MSA Business Performance Indicators
Comments: n order to assess the effectiveness of the measures taken by M&S we will be reviewing the following key performance indicators and reporting on them in future Modern Slavery Statements:• staff training levels;• actions taken to strengthen supply chain auditing and verification; • steps taken to upskill our high risk suppliers, and assessing their ability to detect and mitigate modern slavery risk in supply chains; and• investigations undertaken into reports of Modern Slavery and remedial actions taken in response.

Metric: Walk Free+MSA Business Performance Indicators
Comments: At the end of the MSA on page 10, it has highlighted reporting on KPI's and the next steps ahead in order to emphasis on the development of the current practices along with the introduction of further research, training and support through partnerships. But, as of the 2017/18 statement, there is no disclosure of existing business KPIs that may increase exposure to the risk of modern slavery. Albana Khanna[https://wikirate.org/Albana_Khanna].....2018-10-20 06:33:34 UTC

Metric: Walk Free+MSA Business Performance Indicators
Comments: pg. 9 "REPORTING ON KPIs, AND NEXT STEPS "Actions taken to strengthen supply chain auditing and verification Continued to actively support development of supply chain auditing and verification through SMETA Modern Slavery work, Fast Forward and Responsible Recruitment toolkit. Recognising the limitations of mainstream ethical audits, we have continued to build supplier capacity, and to work with leading forced labour experts on bespoke due diligence audits." ... "Steps taken to upskill our high risk suppliers, and assessing their ability to detect and mitigate modern slavery risk in supply chains We have continued to implement Stronger Together within our Food business and supported the expansion of Stronger Together into South Africa. As described above we have held a flagship conferences in India and Turkey, developed a new International Modern Slavery toolkit in Turkish and supported roll out of Issara responsible recruitment toolkit. We have supported Car wash providers through training and audit and e...

Metric: Walk Free+MSA Business Performance Indicators
Comments: pg. 4 "We recognise the limitation of mainstream ethical audits to identify Modern Slavery issues; and to have effective Modern Slavery due diligence, we need to undertake a range of other methodologies, as appropriate for the nature of the supply chain. Our due diligence over the last year has included: • Bespoke assessments and audits where a previous assessment, intelligence or whistle blower highlights a higher risk in relation to Modern Slavery • In person visits to high risk Food and Clothing & Home supply chain countries • Membership of the Modern Slavery Business Portal for the Food supply chain • A focus on understanding the risks for migrant workers from Myanmar to Thailand in the Food supply chain • Research to understand inter-state labour movement in North India in the Clothing & Home supply chain As we have gone further down into our supply chain, we have also encountered challenges. Metric: Walk Free+MSA Continuous engagement with suppliers
Comments: "We understand that our biggest exposure to Modern Slavery is in our product supply chains, where we have undertaken activity over last decade to minimise the risk of Modern Slavery. Within these areas, new suppliers and factories/sites are subject to due diligence checks in the form of ethical/compliance audits conducted by or on behalf of M&S. Such audits are also regularly conducted for existing suppliers and factories/sites. These audits assess compliance with the Global Sourcing Principles and are, amongst other things, intended to identify any Modern Slavery practices. If issues are identified, appropriate investigative and remedial actions will be taken. During 2015/16, ethical audits identified 14 non-compliances under the heading ‘employment is freely chosen’, this included absence of a clear policy on forced labour, reports from workers that toilet breaks were restricted, deposit payments for protective equipment, and retention of passports of workers. All instances have been followed up, for exa...

Metric: Walk Free+MSA Continuous engagement with suppliers
Comments: 1. "Our Global Sourcing Principles (GSP) have applied to product suppliers since 1998, and as of May 2016, have been extended to all suppliers and franchise partners – including goods not for resale. We updated our standard supplier contractual terms for new suppliers in 2016 and 2017 to include obligations on Modern Slavery Act risk assessment, controls, and notification of Modern Slavery findings and to further reference our wider Global Sourcing Principles. In 2018 we have further strengthened our Global Sourcing Principles, this included clarifying position on non- payment of recruitment fees, expectation on Supplier transparency and requirement for additional due diligence if operating or sourcing in High risk locations. For goods and services not for resale procurement we introduced Supplier management policy which includes Global Sourcing principles to ensure all businesses are captured." (Page 4) Albana Khanna[https://wikirate.org/Albana_Khanna].....2018-10-20 06:20:53 UTC

Metric: Walk Free+MSA Identification of risks
Comments: "In terms of understanding our greatest risk, there are well known reported instances in the food Industry of forced or trafficked labour, ranging from Eastern European workers in the UK meat and poultry processing industry to enslaved migrant workers several tiers down the shrimp supply chain in Thailand. Our human rights risk assessment process has also highlighted the possibility that in service industries, particularly construction and procurements of goods not for resale there could be potential for workers to be put at risk of forced labour. In the clothing industry India arguably represents the biggest risk, because the apparel industry encompasses many different sectors such as cotton, ginning and spinning mills and manufacturing sites. Turkey also has increased in risk given the significant number of foreign migrants. This has enabled us to prioritise our supply chain due diligence on Modern Slavery, which has included working with leading experts on visits to second and third tier sites in our su...

We were the first retailer to initiate a programme of deep dive audits in all the hand car wash companies operating on our premises and to share these results with Gangmaster Licencing Abuse Authority. Partnering with the Fast Forward programme, each provider received training and 1:1 support prior to being audited. The audits revealed that although no evidence of modern slavery was identified, there were significant areas requiring improved labour standards. Metric: Walk Free+MSA risk management (revised)
Comments: pg. 4 "All new and existing direct suppliers to Food and Clothing & Home are required to have ethical audits, conducted by third parties. If issues are identified, appropriate investigative and remedial actions are taken. During 2019/20, ethical audits identified 46 non-compliances compared with 16 in 18/19, under the heading ‘employment is freely chosen’. 29 of the 19/20 non-compliances identified a requirement to improve management systems and policies. The remaining 17 non-compliances covered issues with debt, document retention, termination processes and freedom of movement." In C&H, once a supplier is onboarded, we operate an audit policy that requires an annual social compliance assessment to take place within a 3-month window. This audit cycle is then augmented by our regional compliance team, based in our sourcing offices, who support factories with implementing a corrective action plan. In Food, suppliers are risk assessed and the audit programme is designed around the results of those assessments." ... We publish the M&S interactive supply chain map, disclosing our tier one supply chain across Food and Clothing & Home. The scope has been extended to include some raw materials including wool, man-made cellulosic fibres, beef, fish & seafood, dairy, tea and coffee and is updated on a 6-monthly basis. 3 Goods Not for Resale (“GNFR”) Our GNFR category includes those products and services we buy to run our business – such as professional services, store equipment, design services and stationery. Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A01.EA Sustainability Strategy Disclosure
Comments: The company discloses that it has assessed the material sustainability topics with its key stakeholders in the reporting year. Also, it discloses that it included climate related risks in determining materiality. However, no evidence found that the company discloses the process of identification and the list of material issues identified.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A01.EB Sustainability Strategy Coverage
Comments: The company has a sustainability strategy that covers its contribution to the pressures on nature and considers the links between nature and people and their livelihoods. However, no evidence found that the company has a sustainability strategy which is based on an assessment of its impact on the state of nature.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A01.EC Group-Wide Sustainability Strategy
Comments: The company discloses its time-bound targets related to ecosystem conversion, climate, nutrition, and social inclusion. However, no evidence that the company has time-bound and measurable targets for topics such as biodiversity, water, and soil health.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A01.ED Sustainability Strategy Reporting
Comments: The company discloses progress against all its target, however, no evidence found that it discloses a baseline year against all of the targets it has set.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A01 Sustainability Strategy

World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A02 Accountability for Sustainable Strategy+World Benchmarking Alliance Research Group
World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A02.EA Responsibility for Sustainable Strategy
Comments: The company discloses that it has an ESG Committee, chaired by Tamara Ingram, which is responsible for the implementation of its sustainability strategy.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A02.EB Accountability for Sustainable Strategy Assignation
Comments: The company discloses that its non-executive director i.e. Tamara Ingram, chairs the ESG Committee which ensures that the company has an Environmental, Social, and Governance strategy, reviews the effectiveness of the strategy and approves and recommends all ESG reporting for the board’s approval.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A02.EC Accountability for Sustainable Strategy Remuneration
Comments: The company discloses that it has decided not to introduce an environmental, social, and governance (ESG) measure in the performance criteria for senior executives' remuneration policies in the reporting year.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A02.ED Accountability for Sustainable Strategy Evidence
Comments: The company discloses that its board members have expertise in women's leadership, development of the sustainability strategy 'Net Positive', health and wellbeing, diversity, human rights, and environmental science.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A03.EA Stakeholder Engagement Issue Disclosure
Comments: The company provides an overview of the issues raised during its stakeholder engagement activities, from shareholders, colleagues, customers, communities, suppliers, and partners. Also, it discloses the concerns, priorities, and expectations expressed by each stakeholder group, ranging from the reinstatement of dividends for shareholders to addressing the cost-of-living crisis for colleagues, emphasizing sustainability for customers and communities, and focusing on fair payment terms and recovery efforts for suppliers.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A03.EB Stakeholder Engagement Identification
Comments: No evidence found that the company discloses its process for identifying relevant stakeholders across its value chain.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A03.EC Stakeholder Engagement Process Disclosure
Comments: The company discloses the channels through which it engages with each stakeholder group that includes meetings, surveys, consultations.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A03.ED Stakeholder Engagement Outcomes
Comments: The company responds to each group's concerns, from addressing financial pressures for colleagues to reducing plastic packaging for environmentally conscious customers.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A03.EE Stakeholder Engagement Coverage
Comments: The company's stakeholders' issues include aspects related to environmental impact and sustainability, and social issues like managing the cost-of-living crisis for colleagues, however, no evidence found that the stakeholder engagement covers biodiversity and social aspects including diversity, inclusion or women's representation.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A03 Stakeholder Engagement

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A04.EB Lobbying and Advocacy Assessment Framework
Comments: No evidence found that the company discloses a clear and detailed framework for assessing alignment of its trade associations with nature-positive policies.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A04.EC Lobbying and Advocacy Framework Application

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A04.EF Lobbying and Advocacy Misalignment Escalation Action Plan Deadlines

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A04.EG Lobbying and Advocacy Annual Review Disclosure

World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A04 Lobbying and advocacy+World Benchmarking Alliance Research Group
World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A05.EA Circular and Nature-Positive Transition Assessment
Comments: No evidence found that the company assesses the risks and opportunities related to the transition to a circular economy and determines the impacts of staying in a linear economy.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A05.EB Circular and Nature-Positive Transition Group-Level Evidence
Comments: The company discloses that it is committed to driving circularity and sending zero waste to landfill from its own operations and construction activities in the UK and Republic of Ireland. Also, it states that it has identified circular economy as one of its 10 key pillars in its net zero by 2040 strategy and it is actively working across its value chain to drive circularity and reduce waste in various areas, including used clothing, food waste, packaging, and carrier bags.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A05.EC Circular and Nature-Positive Transition Strategy Disclosure
Comments: The company discloses the initiatives taken to deliver a net increase in biodiversity around the Cheshire Oaks store. Also, it discloses that it is a signatory to WWF’s Retailers’ Commitment for Nature, which works to halt the loss of nature and as part of this it has committed to halve the environmental impact of the UK’s shopping baskets by 2030, however, no evidence found that the company discloses a strategy that would lead its business model to become nature-positive, which includes a time-frame in line with milestones for halting biodiversity loss (no net loss) and reversing the trend (biodiversity net gain).

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.A05.ED Circular and Nature-Positive Transition Mitigation Hierarchy
Comments: No evidence found that the company applies a mitigation hierarchy approach to its biodiversity targets.

World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B05.EA Zero Ecosystem Conversion Commitment
Comments: The company provides a commitment to achieve zero conversion for its soy, palm oil, and animal feed supply chain. However, no evidence found that the company commits to achieving zero conversion throughout its supply chains for all its relevant high-risk commodities, such as cocoa and coffee.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B05.EB Zero Ecosystem Conversion Evidence
Comments: The company discloses its engagement with suppliers in the soy supply chain and requires all its key suppliers, including suppliers of dairy products and finished product manufacturers, to provide information on their soy footprint, and the response rate to its soy survey went from 76% in 2021 to 95% in 2022. Further, it discloses that is tracking two sustainability metrics for its soy i.e. % Verified Deforestation and Conversion Free (vDCF) which includes transitionary mechanisms, such as mass balance, area mass balance, segregated or RTRS regional credits and % Physically Certified Deforestation and Conversion Free for which evidence is required of supply claimed to meet a relevant physically certified standard. Also, it discloses that in 2022, supplier indicated a total usage of 39,127 tonnes of vDCF soy, compared to 31,596 tonnes in the previous year. Furthermore, it discloses that 39% of all sourced soy was vDCF, and 98% of palm oil in the company's own-label food products was segregated RSPO certifie...

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B05.EC Zero Ecosystem Conversion Time-Bound Targets
Comments: The company discloses that by 2025/26, 100% of soy will be sourced from verified deforestation and conversion-free regions, and 100% segregated RSPO-certified palm oil will be included in its label products. However, the company does not have a time-bound target to achieve zero conversion for all relevant high-risk commodities, including coffee, cocoa, and paper.

World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B06.EA Ecosystem Restoration Commitment
Comments: The company discloses its commitment to source fabrics that do not originate from the world's remaining ancient and endangered forests and to support lasting restoration and conservation solution for those regions. Also, it is committed to working with industry and NGO partners to shift the fabric supply chain towards sourcing practices that ensure protection of the world’s remaining ancient and endangered forests and endangered species habitat. Further, it states that is working with industry, governments, academics and civil society to support the protection of ancient and endangered forests and find solutions to reduce demand on forests. Additionally, it pledges support for enduring restoration and conservation solutions in these regions.

World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B08.EA Improving Soil Health and Increasing Agrobiodiversity Evidence
Comments: The company discloses that it focuses on regenerative agriculture practices in its indicator and innovative farm network and has launched its wildfarmed bread that is made from regeneratively farmed wheat. Also, it discloses that it is exploring the opportunities for adoption of regenerative agriculture practices in its potato production. Further, it discloses that a project in its potato-supply chain works to understand how different agricultural practices and cover crops can reduce the carbon footprint of potato farms with a focus on regenerative agriculture. Moreover, it discloses that it sources its cotton fibres from programmes that benefit farmers and promote soil health.

Comments: The company discloses that it collaborates with stakeholders, including WWF, to understand the impact of water stresses on its business. Further, it discloses that it recognizes Western Cape as a water risk hotspot and works with Woolworths, WWF, and AWS to implement international standards with customized water stewardship plans for each farm. However, no evidence found that the company has a target to engage with upstream business partners on the management of water-stressed areas, and reports progress against it.

Comments: The company expects its suppliers to treat effluents in a fully functional effluent treatment plant (ETP) before being discharged. Also, it states that it will not do business with mills that discharge untreated effluent directly into water courses. World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B11.EA Hazardous Substances Reduction Evidence
Comments: The company discloses that it has banned the use of hazardous chemicals such as alkylphenol ethoxylates. Further, the company requires its suppliers to register on the ZDHC Gateway, which helps the suppliers to get access to a database of MRSL-compliant chemistry. Moreover, it discloses that it engages in a number of programmes with the Zero Discharge of Hazardous Chemicals Foundation (ZDHC) and the Sustainable Apparel Coalition (SAC) to aid its suppliers in reducing their environmental impact.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B11.EB Hazardous Substances Phase-Out Targets
Comments: No evidence found that the company has targets towards phasing out the production of hazardous substances or increasing the production of safer alternatives, and reports progress against it.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B11.EC SVHC (substance of very high concern) Commitment
Comments: The company discloses that it prohibits the use of products or preparations containing substance of very high concern where viable alternatives are available. However, no evidence found that the company commits not to develop or market new chemicals or products with SVHC (substance of very high concern) properties, even in the absence of alternative solutions.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B11.ED Hazardous Waste Reduction Evidence
Comments: The company discloses that it aims to avoid the use of banned substances during production and manufacturing and ensures that hazardous chemicals are not discharged to the environment, but does not report on waste.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B11.EE Hazardous Waste Reduction Targets
Comments: No evidence found that the company has set targets towards reducing total amounts of hazardous waste, and reports progress against it.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B11.EF Hazardous Waste Reporting
Comments: No evidence found that the company reports on the proportion of hazardous waste treated to reduce pollution compared to total waste, hazardous waste diverted from disposal and directed to disposal.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B11 Hazardous substances and waste
World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B11 Hazardous substances and waste+World Benchmarking Alliance Research Group
World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B12.EA Plastic Use and Waste Reduction Qualitative Evidence
Comments: The company is actively addressing plastic packaging issues and supporting the UK Plastics Pact. Further, it discloses projects aimed at eliminating plastic packaging from various food items, including croissants, nuts, teacakes, and tomatoes. This involves transitioning croissants to cardboard trays, introducing new pouch packaging for on-the-go nuts, implementing plastic-free packaging for teacakes, shifting tomatoes to cardboard trays, and promoting customer reuse and return of laundry and homecare products to minimize plastic usage.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B12.EB Plastic Use and Waste Reduction Quantitative Evidence
Comments: The company discloses that it has reduced plastic usage across various sectors, 75 million pieces of plastic were eliminated in 2021/22 in food business, over 3,000 tonnes of packaging, including black plastic and polystyrene, have been removed since 2018 and in clothing & homes business, 60 million plastic units were eliminated in 2018.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B12.EC Plastic Use and Waste Reduction Targets
Comments: The company discloses that it aims to eliminate 1 billion units of plastic from its packaging portfolio by the end of 2027/28, from a base year of 2017/18. Further, it reports that 75 million pieces of plastic packaging have been removed in the year 2022/23.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B12.ED Plastic Use Reporting
Comments: The company discloses that 5000 tonnes of plastic hangers are collected and returned to suppliers for reuse. Further, it discloses that it has reused and recycled over 1 billion plastic hangers in the last 12 years. However, no evidence found that it provides metrics of its reused or recycled products overall.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B12.EE Plastic Waste Reporting
Comments: No evidence found that the company reports on the amount of plastic waste generated, and proportions directed from or to disposal.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B12.EF Plastic Use and Waste Reduction Evidence Upstream
Comments: The company discloses that it is operating a closed-loop hanger recycling program under which it is encouraging customers to return hangers which are sent back to garment suppliers for reuse. Also, it is working with supplier partners to make them understand where they can remove hangers before despatching online orders and for the remaining small amount of other plastic product packaging used in its clothing business, it is consistently making changes to packaging design to reduce the overall usage of plastic items.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B12.EG Plastic Use and Waste Reduction Evidence Downstream
Comments: The company has launched a new click-and-collect initiative called Bring Your Own Bag to reduce the use of plastic packaging. However, it does not disclose on more material topics, such as production, in its downstream activities.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B12 Plastic use and waste
World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B12 Plastic use and waste+World Benchmarking Alliance Research Group

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.B14.EB Scope 1 and 2 Greenhouse Gas Emissions Targets

World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.C01.EA Right to a Safe, Clean, Healthy, and Sustainable Environment Commitment
Comments: The company states that it is committed to ensuring the health, safety and wellbeing of its colleagues, customers and others who visit or work on its premises. However, no evidence found that the company has a policy commitment to respect the right to a safe, clean, healthy, and sustainable environment of local communities.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.C01.EB Impacts Identification Process includes Focus on Health of Local Communities
Comments: The company discloses that it carried out a comprehensive assessment to define its salient human rights issues that includes health and safety, however, it is unclear whether its human rights risks and impacts identification process includes a focus on the health of local communities.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.C01.EC Tracking Negative Impact on Local Communities

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.C01.ED Preventing/Mitigating/Remediating Negative Impact on Local Communities

World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.C02.EA Indigenous People' Rights Commitment
Comments: No evidence found that the company commits to respect Indigenous Peoples’ rights or references the relevant part(s) of ILO Convention No. 169 on Indigenous and Tribal Peoples or the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.C02.EB Indigenous People' Rights Impact Identification
Comments: No evidence found that the company discloses its processes to identify and recognize the rights of Indigenous Peoples when activities in its operations may impact their rights, and describes how it obtains Indigenous Peoples’ free, prior, and informed consent regarding whether and how to carry out projects.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.C02.EC Business Relationships & Indigenous People' Rights Requirements
Comments: The company requires its suppliers to recognize the right of Indigenous Peoples and rural communities to give or withhold their Free, Prior, and Informed Consent (FPIC) before new logging rights are allocated or plantations are developed.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.C02.ED Business Relationships & Indigenous People' Rights Practices

World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.C03.EA Land Rights Commitment
Comments: No evidence found that the company has a commitment to respect ownership and use of land and natural resources and related legitimate tenure rights, as set out in the relevant part(s) of the CFS Voluntary Guidelines on the Responsible Governance of Tenure of Land, Fisheries and Forests in the Context of National Food Security (VGGTs), or the IFC Performance Standards.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.C03.EB Land Acquisition Engagement
Comments: No evidence found that the company when acquiring, leasing land, or making other arrangements to use or restrict the use or access to land or natural resources, discloses its processes to identify legitimate tenure rightsholders, including through engagement with affected communities in the process, paying particular attention to vulnerable or marginalized tenure rightsholders, and negotiate with them to provide adequate compensation.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.C03.EC Business Relationships Requirements of Land Rights
Comments: The company requires its business relationships to adhere to the practice of free and prior informed consent (FPIC) when using, leasing, and purchasing land.

Metric: World Benchmarking Alliance+NAT.C03.ED Business Relationships Land Rights Practices
Comments: No evidence found that the company works with its business relationships to improve their practices on land use and acquisition.

Dina Seyer+Partnering with charities
Comments: Our continued work on food waste has also shown that we can donate more unsold food to the community through our charitable partners (Company Shop, FareShare, FoodCycle and Neighbourly). These schemes can redistribute surplus food from the back of our stores to a wide range of charities that cook for those in need and are on the frontline of dealing with food poverty. We have been running a number of trials across the country (operating in 45 stores) to establish the best model for getting our surplus food to those who need it whilst maintaining our visibility and traceability of these items. As a result, from October 2015 we commenced roll out of a nationwide charitable redistribution scheme using Neighbourly as a platform connecting every store with existing and new local charity partners to maximise the amount of food that can be redistributed.

Aileen Rob+RE100 Company
Theresa Rabing+Recycling Leftover Food
Comments: We are able to donate various bakery products, produce, flowers and ambient products. By law we are unable to donate any products that have gone past their ‘use by’ date but this is an area the industry is doing some research into. As a largely chilled business this is especially pertinent to us and is of particular interest. Having said this, the current categories of donated products represent up to 45% of our daily waste units. Whilst we’re doing as much as possible to reduce the amount of waste we create in the first place and redistributing what we can there is inevitably a residual portion of waste. This is sent to anaerobic digestion plants. This ultimately creates electricity some of which MS buys back for its own energy supply and produces digestate which can be used as a fertiliser.

Metric: Wikirate SDG Metric design+SDG13 (Climate Action) Actions
Value: Yes, and they are related to the company's material operations
Comments: TO BECOME A ZERO-WASTE BUSINESS (PAGE 24) HEADLINE TARGETS –By 2020, 100% of M&S products will have at least one Plan A attribute and by 2025 every product will have attributes which address all priority social, ethical and environmental impacts. –By 2022, all M&S product packaging in the UK that could end up with our customers will be not only ‘recyclable, but ‘widely recycled’. To achieve this, we will actively collaborate with others to bring about changes in local government recycling policy. By 2022, we will also assess the feasibility of making all M&S plastic packaging from one polymer group, which will help maximise the use of recycled content. –By 2025, the 50 key raw materials used for M&S products will come from sources verified as respecting the integrity of ecosystems, the welfare of animals and the wellbeing of people and communities. This will cover over 80% of M&S raw material usage by volume. Anh Nguyen[https://wikirate.org/Anh_Nguyen].....2020-05-12 05:15:46 UTC - This year, we launched n...

Metric: Wikirate SDG Metric design+SDG13 (Climate Action) Actions
Value: Yes, and they are related to the company's material operations
Comments: To take a lead in responding to the global concerns over pollution from plastic we’ve developed a set of five Plastic Principles (Re-use, Re-design, Re-duce, Re-turn and Re-cycle). We’re working on projects to eliminate 1,000 tonnes of plastic packaging usage and our plastic-free fruits and vegetables trial has just been extended to a further two stores. (Page 18) 70% of all M&S product packaging that ends up with our customers is classified as being widely recycled in the UK. We’re aiming to make it all widely recycled or recycled in store as soon as possible. (Page 20) This year, the total amount of waste generated by our stores, offices and warehouses in the UK and ROI was down by 7% on last year. For the seventh consecutive year, the amount sent to landfill was zero. (Page 20) Anh Nguyen[https://wikirate.org/Anh_Nguyen].....2020-05-06 13:17:11 UTC

Scope 1 and 2 emissions are only part of the picture. Our biggest carbon impact – in fact more than 97% – comes from Scope 3 emissions, or in other words, emissions from how our suppliers source and make our fantastic products, as well as how our customers use them.  In 2012, we became the first major retailer in the UK and ROI to achieve carbon neutral status.

Metric: Global Reporting Initiative+Total Waste Recycled, GRI 306-2 (formerly G4-EN23-a)
Comments: Our MS operated stores, offices and warehouses in the UK and Republic of Ireland produce around 80,000 tonnes of waste all of which is valued and retained in the economy in some form. The majority is either transit packaging, such as cardboard and polythene, or unsold food which cannot be donated to charities. The small amount of damaged or impact clothing generated in our stores is donated to Oxfam or Newlife. We send no operational waste to landfill and have been working hard to reduce the waste we create. We’re also continually improving our approach to fitting out our stores by seeking ways to reuse and refurbish equipment. We estimate that used products and packaging from customers generates over 400,000 tonnes of materials with just over half likely to be reused or recycled. The remainder will be sent to some form of municipal disposal. Based on our market share, our customers will be producing around 250,000 tonnes of food waste with around a third being composted or recovered in some form and 100,0...

Metric: Global Reporting Initiative+Total Waste to Landfill, GRI 306-2 (formerly G4-EN23-a)
Comments: In February 2012, MS achieved our zero waste to landfill commitment – ensuring that all of our operational and construction waste (from every one of our MS operated stores, offices and warehouses) in the UK and Republic of Ireland is sent for reuse or recycling. They spent over 18 months developing a strategy to ensure it was feasible, robust and commercially viable. Waste had previously been managed directly by different parts of the business. For example, arrangements in our clothing warehouses differed to those in our stores and again in our offices. We realised that this was inefficient and would prevent us delivering our target, so we agreed that responsibility for waste should be centralised. Some areas of the business, such as logistics, were deriving revenue from recycling which was factored into their operating plans. Other parts of the business had to make additional investments. Over the period of 3 years we restructured our operating plans and moved funding between areas to enable us to put in ...
